heading: What is a PWA?
content: A PWA is a web app that takes advantage of modern browser features to achieve the reliability, quickness, and engagement of native apps.

heading: A Better Definition
content:
"This is how we should build websites."

At its core, a PWA is just a way to optimize your code for better, faster delivery. Every website can benefit from that.

Like "responsive design," the term "PWA" is more of a buzzword for the collection of underlying technologies it represents.

heading: Benefits of a PWA
content:
• Benefits over traditional websites or web apps
  • Benefits over native apps

heading: Benefits over traditional websites or web apps
content:
• Can be "installed" on a user’s home screen
  • Works reliably across poor or non-existent network conditions
  • Improved performance thanks to smart caching
  • User engagement via push notifications
  • Your website does not need to be a "web app" or a "SPA" to be upgraded to a PWA

heading: Benefits over native apps
content:
• PWA development and maintenance costs are much lower than a native app
  • No hassle of third-party app stores
  • Nearly instantaneous installs
  • Better search engine visibility

heading: New Technology
content:
• Middleman between web app and the browser/network
  • Can intercept resource requests and take appropriate action based on conditions like network availability and updated assets on server
  • Can run in the background, without your PWA open in the browser
  • Cache content for instant access and offline availability
  • Tools exist to generate service workers for common scenarios like precaching resources
  • Browser support is crap right now

heading: New Technology
content:
• Gives web apps the ability to receive messages pushed to them from a server, whether or not the web app is in the foreground, or even currently loaded
  • Requires an active service worker
  • Browser support is crap right now
